intro.description: Once we're confident in the set of target legs we can move on to capture more of the analyst's knowledge and refine the target track.

item.title: Introduce speed constraint
item.description: For this hypothetical engagement, whilst we didn't have target track data, we did have a record of target speed. We're going to add it here.

item.title: Add Speed constraint
item.description:
We can add a speed constraint in a number of ways. At the per-leg level we can expand a Straight Leg Forecast and enter min/max/estimate values for course or speed for each leg.
Alternatively we can apply a speed constraint to the whole engagement. Do this by right-clicking on the Bearing Data item in the Outline view and selecting Add speed forecast for period covered by [Selected Legs]. When the popup box opens, enter Overall speed to name the contribution.
As the contribution gets added you will see the target solution disappear, since its no longer valid.

item.title: Specify speed constraint
item.description:
Now we must enter the actual constraint in the Speed Forecast control in the Maintain Contributions view. The exercise observer recorded that the target was doing around 9 knots during the whole exercise. So, to allow for speed keeping errors, enter a minimum speed of 8 knots, a maximum speed of 10 knots, and an (optional) estimate of 9 knots.
Then re-run the Calculate Solution button. In the Performance tab you will see the effectiveness of both the Bearing Data and the Overall speed estimates. The bars are shaded according to the respective color-coded constraint.

item.title: Generate manual TMA solution
item.description:
As previously we finish off the TMA generation process by developing a manual TMA solution. Right-click on the TMA solution in the Outline view, and select Convert to Composite Track (legs).
A manual solution will now appear in the Outline view, and the auto TMA solution will be hidden. Mark the new solution as a Secondary track by selecting it in the Outline view then clicking on the 2 in the Outline view toolbar.
Were now ready to manually adjust the solution.

item.title: Tune manual TMA solution
item.description:
Start manually tuning the TMA solution by clicking on the Drag Track Segment mouse mode button on the main application toolbar. As you click on it, the Bearing Residuals window will open.
If the Bearing Residuals window is empty, open the Track Tote and double-check that your primary track Ownship and secondary track 121200.00_0 are assigned.
Alternatively, if the ownship sensor cuts are not visible, you will need to clear the Only draw dots for visible sensor points check button in the Bearing Residuals view toolbar.
Now select Shear drag mode in the Bearing Residuals window and start dragging track segments to minimise the bearing errors.
Don't worry if your track segment dragging results in a mangled solution, you can just just delete the manual track from the Outline view and generate a new one from your existing solution.

item.title: Merge track segments
item.description:
When you are finally happy with your solution its time to merge the separate track segments into a formal track.
To do this, you need to expand your manual TMA solution in the Outline view, then right-click on the Track Segments (5) item. From the popup list, select Merge all track segments.
You now have a track for the subject vessel that you can use for your further analysis.

item.title: Mark your answers
item.description:
What? You want to know how well you did?
Simple, the truth track for the problem is the Subject track in the Outline view. Just make it visible and compare how your solution looks against it.
If you'd like a more quantitative score, produce an XY Plot of range between your solution and the truth track. You should be able to achieve an accuracy of around 200 yds - not bad when we're using sensor data at around 20000 yds.
